text: India is expected to see a capacity addition from 442 GW in Fiscal 2024 to 700 GW to 710 GW in Fiscal 2029. This addition of capacities will further push to increase transmission lines and sub stations of high voltage as well as upgradation of existing transmission lines. (Source: CRISIL Report) Investments of ₹ 29 trillion to 30 trillion in the Indian power sector between Fiscal 2026 and 2030. Investments in power generation are expected to increase approximately 1.7 times from ₹ 11.6 trillion between Fiscals 2019 and 2025 to ₹ 19 trillion to 21 trillion between Fiscals 2026 and 2030. (Source: CRISIL Report) Investments in renewable energy (excluding hydro, pumped storage and BESS) generation capacity are expected to account for 70% of these investments over the same period as India seeks to achieve its 500 GW of non-fossil energy capacity announced in 26th Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (“COP26”).

Similarly, the world's electricity consumption is projected to experience its fastest growth in years till 2027, driven by factors such as increasing industrial activity, greater use of air conditioning, rapid electrification, and the global expansion of data centers. After a 4.3% increase in 2024, global electricity demand is expected to continue growing at a rate of nearly 4% until 2027. Over the next three years, the world's electricity consumption is forecast to increase by a significant 3,500 terawatt hours. The majority of the world's increased electricity demand until 2027 is anticipated to come from emerging economies, accounting for 85% of the growth.

We believe that our vast experience and market position will allow us to capitalize on industry trends and fundamental growth drivers in the Power T&D industry. However, our growth will be adversely impacted by any significant slow-downs in economic growth, which results in reduction in power consumption and could result in shifts of government policy away from Power T&D projects. Further, our business is exposed to risks in relation to shift in government policies, delayed implementation of distribution and transmission projects and shift in budgetary allocations to the power sector. A growth of the power sector on account of government's strong focus and budgetary allocations will improve our business and prospectus and conversely a general slowdown in the economy and reduction in budgetary allocation to the power sector will adversely impact our business and financials.
## Ability to maintain and grow demand for our products

We manufacture and supply a wide range of overhead conductors, power cables, optical ground wire (“OPGW”), and provide master system integration (“MSI”) services. According to the CRISIL Report, in India, the transmission and distribution sector is a three tiered system comprising of distribution networks, state grids and regional grids. The demand for cables is driven by distribution, consumer, infra, and data center growth, while conductors are driven more by transmission expansion, renewable energy evacuation, and replacement of legacy lines. Together, both benefit from global electrification, energy transition, artificial intelligence and electric vehicles growth and infrastructure build-out.

In Fiscal 2025, power transmission cables formed the highest market share in the overall domestic cables and wire industry at 34% to 36%. (Source: CRISIL Report) The high share of power transmission cables is owing to favourable government initiatives in the power segment such as rural electrification schemes and railway electrification. (Source: CRISIL Report) Addition to transmission lines and railway electrification are the major factors influencing the demand in conductors. (Source: CRISIL Report) The capex across all these is driven by the government and any slowdown in the same will impact the demand for cables and conductors. The conductor industry in India is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 5% to 6% from Fiscal 2025 to Fiscal 2030 to reach ₹ 230 billion to ₹ 250 billion by Fiscal 2029 due to ongoing government schemes in power segment as well increased exports of conductors from India. (Source: CRISIL Report). Further, according to the CRISIL Report, the wires and cables market size is expected to grow at a CAGR of 11% to 13% between Fiscal 2025 and Fiscal 2030 reaching ₹3,350 billion to ₹ 3,550 billion by Fiscal 2030 due to ongoing infrastructure development projects, surge in construction activities and increasing digital connectivity. Major factors contributing to this growth included an overall upswing in exports, favourable government initiatives such as the REC, rural electrification programs and demand stemming from various segments. Notably, the production of HV and EHV cables (above 33 KV) registered a strong CAGR of 53.8% from Fiscal 2019 to Fiscal 2025, primarily due to increased investments in power transmission infrastructure and ambitious grid modernization projects supporting renewable energy integration. (Source: CRISIL Report) Further, investments in power generation are expected to increase approximately 1.7 times from ₹ 11.6 trillion between Fiscals 2019 to 2025 to ₹ 19 trillion to ₹ 21 trillion between Fiscals 2026 to 2030. Investments in renewable energy (excluding hydro, pumped storage and BESS) generation capacity are expected to account for 70% of these investments over the same period as India seeks to achieve its 500 GW of non-fossil energy capacity announced in COP26. In addition, data centre capacity in the country has grown from 350 MW in Fiscal 2019 to 1150 MW to 1250 MW in Fiscal 2025 and expected to reach to 2000 MW to 2300 MW by Fiscal 2027 which will also drive strong power demand. For further details in relation to the growth of overhead conductors and cables, see “Our Business” on page 222 and “Industry Overview” on page 146.

We expect this growth to result in an increase in demand of our products. However, the demand for our products may decrease, either because of a deterioration in macroeconomic conditions or because of lack of government support for additional distribution and transmission projects, or our competitors selling similar products at a lower cost.
